title: Ketosis for cancer and chronic disease
content: Update on Dom’s Press-pulse therapeutic strategy for the metabolic management of cancer [2:05]. Dom’s Press-Pulse paper with Tom Seyfried from 2017: Press-pulse: a novel therapeutic strategy for the metabolic management of cancer. Dom discussed this paper on his first appearance on The Drive podcast. Tom Seyfried has also previously discussed the Press-Pulse approach with Peter.

title: The effect of ketosis on female health
content: The podcast discusses the effect of ketosis on female health.

title: Nutrition and Ketone Metabolic Therapy for Cancer Treatment
content: The idea of using ketone metabolic therapy (or therapeutic ketosis) and other modalities to compromise tumor growth and proliferation. This weakens the tumor making it more susceptible to be killed by other modalities. Example, the ketogenic diet combined with hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT). Being in a state of therapeutic ketosis suppresses insulin signaling, which drives PI-3 kinase, lowers glucose availability to the tumor, and elevates ketone bodies which can not be readily utilized by most cancers as a source of fuel. Ketones also impair antioxidant pathways that the tumors use to defend itself (e.g., the pentose phosphate pathway generates more glutathione in cancer cells and that is being fed by glucose). In summary—if you reduce glucose availability and inhibit insulin, which suppresses glycolysis, you’re creating a scenario where if you give an oxidative challenge with hyperbaric oxygen therapy, you can potentially kill the cancer cells. The ketogenic diet and hyperbaric oxygen therapy prolong survival in mice with systemic metastatic cancer. Many different things that you can combine in press-pulse therapy. A weakened tumor from therapeutic ketosis may be more vulnerable to a number of other cancer specific metabolic drugs—PI3K inhibitors, 2-Deoxy-d-glucose, 3-Bromopyruvate (3BP), Dichloroacetate (DCA), Metformin, Vitamin C at high doses, and SGLT2 inhibitors.

title: Vitamin C as a Pro-oxidant in Cancer Treatment
content: Most people think of vitamin C as an antioxidant, but high concentrations of vitamin C can be a prooxidant–making it relevant in cancer treatment. Dom and team has done in vitro experiments with high doses of vitamin C—presented by Janine Deblasi, now PhD student researcher. Potential role for vitamin C in cancer treatment.

title: Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy and Radiation Therapy for Cancer Treatment
content: Radiation therapy kills cancer cells by 80 to 90% just through reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation because they are toxic tumor cells. The efficacy of radiation therapy is directly proportional to the pO2 of the tumor—so if you oxygenate the tumor and then radiate it there is a greater burst of intr-tumor ROS. Tumors tend to grow and outstrip their blood supply, so they’re hypoxic, making them resistant to radiation. So adding HBOT during radiation would dramatically sensitize it. After having hyperbaric oxygen therapy, you’ll have a residual elevation of reactive oxygen species for hours after. And it’ll be somewhat site-specific increase in reactive oxygen species, because various mitochondrial abnormalities. There’s a debate whether the mitochondria are damaged or they are not damaged.

title: The double benefit of vitamin C
content: Dehydroascorbic acid—the oxidized form of vitamin C—uses the glucose transporter to get inside cells. So if you elevate this form of vitamin C into millimolar concentrations in the blood using an IV, it functions as a glucose antagonist to the point where you may have hypoglycemic symptoms. So you are delivering a glucose antagonist that’s also dramatically increasing reactive oxygen species in cancer cells because tumors have a lot of free heme (iron). “[Vitamin C is] a really important component now, we think, to the press-pulse concept of cancer management.”

title: Glutamine targeting in cancer therapy—evidence that the mitochondria in cancer are damaged?
content: Literature suggests that tumor cells can be “addicted” to glutamine (i.e., mitochondrial substrate level phosphorylation with glutamine). Tom Seyfried has experimented with combining calorie-restricted ketogenic diet and glutamine targeting in late-stage experimental glioblastoma. He is using his VM-M3 glioblastoma mice (glioblastoma that has metastasized). Dom published a paper with Andrew Koutnik which demonstrated that the VM-M3 mouse model is a superior model to study cancer metastasis and cachexia.

title: Can a ketogenic diet lessen the toxicity of cancer therapies?
content: Tom Seyfried mentioned in his paper that there was less toxicity associated with giving DON when the mice were on a ketogenic diet when compared to a standard diet.

title: Ketogenic diet and cancer therapies
content: Starting a ketogenic diet (especially calorie-restricted) “sets the stage” for cancer therapies to work— suppression of insulin signaling, decreasing glucose availability, limiting glutamine availability. Lowering of many of the amino acids and associated anabolic signals that can drive tumor growth. You do all that and cripple antioxidant defenses by reducing pentose phosphate pathway activity. It’s possible to “set the stage” nicely for an oxidative stress stimulus that could kill the cancer — therapies like: A drug therapy — with PI 3-kinase drug, you get results, but it’s nothing like if you start the diet a week or two before. Hyperbaric oxygen. IV vitamin C (functions as a pro-oxidant). Chemotherapy—which is a form of metabolic therapy, since you’re inhibiting the formation of molecules and crippling the mitochondria to some extent and their ability to make ATP. Radiation (kills cancer primarily through  oxidative stress). IV vitamin C hyperbaric oxygen, and, of course, radiation and chemo (combined). Many chemotherapeutic agents kill cancer cells through a redox mechanism… Metformin, for example, has anticancer effects which are linked mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS production. 3BP—a promising agent in cancer therapy. Dom calls 3BP—a hexokinase-2 inhibitor—an enormously promising agent. Detractors will says that 2-DG is cardiotoxic—which is true at high enough doses—but it also seems to have anticancer effects. Dom’s understanding is that for 3BP to have an anticancer effect and also to be nontoxic, it needs to be delivered in a very specific way, ideally site-specific in a liposomal preparation. But the waters have been muddied with a lot of competing interests and legal disputes (more about this in the book). Dom would love to include 3BP in his experiments in the future under the mentorship of Dr. Young Ko. He’s hopeful that clinical trials will start and more animal research will indicate the best way to use these compounds.

title: The relationship between cancer and ketogenic diets
content: Suggested literature on this topic: Comprehensive review on Keto Diet and Cancer : Ketogenic diet in the treatment of cancer – Where do we stand? Ketogenic Diet and Drug Synergy under investigation: A 2-Week Ketogenic Diet in Combination With Letrozole to Modulate PI3K Signaling in ER+ Breast Cancer (Vanderbilt). The latest. 10 years ago, there was very little on clinicaltrials.gov. Now there’s about 40 preclinical trials (animals and humans) on clinicaltrials.gov. Some of the most promising work is with Lew Cantley, using a diet plus drug combination.

title: What types of cancers are most responsive to a ketogenic diet?
content: Many cancers have a metabolic cause— Ovarian, Endometrial, Breast cancer, GI cancers especially, Liver, Gallbladder, Colon, Stomach, Esophagus. *Dom points out that pretty much all cancers grow in part through the activation PI3 kinase being driven by insulin. A Nature Communications paper showed that even the KRAS mutation (previously thought not to be responsive to a ketogenic diet) might actually be responsive to a keto diet—KRAS mutations associated with different lung cancers, pancreas, and colon cancer did respond.

title: Are there any situations where the ketogenic diet would fuel tumor growth?
content: A recent paper that came out suggesting dietary fat intake might promote the growth of melanoma tumors harboring BRAF V600E mutations. Tuberous sclerosis complex is another tricky type cancer where has either no effect or maybe even a pro tumor effect. Blood cancers (e.g., lymphoma)—the ketogenic diet may not be right choice. There are blood cancer exceptions, such as AML—Lew Cantley showed that the ketogenic diet with the PI3 kinase inhibitor may be responsive in the context of insulin suppression (with ketogenic diet) combined with PI3K inhibition.

title: HBOT Protocol for Cancer Research
content: Using info from the existing literature and preclinical animal models, they used the following protocol with the goal of killing a tumor—2.5 atmospheres of oxygen, 60-90 minutes, 3 times per week. Instead of doing it five days continuously—which they would use for wound healing—you need a break to allow adaptation and recovery from the high dose of oxygen before you hit it again. Dom hasn’t done the experiment yet, but he thinks it would be best to combine that with IV vitamin C and some other drugs as well.

title: A Primer on Atmospheric Pressure
content: At sea level, 20% of the air that you’re breathing is oxygen—so that’s 0.2 atmospheres absolute oxygen. If you’re breathing 100% oxygen off a mask in a room filled completely with oxygen, that would be 1.0 ATA. Every atmosphere is like 33 feet of seawater or 10 meters… so 2.5 atmospheres would be 15 meters. Once the hemoglobin is saturated, the increase in barometric pressure pushes the oxygen into the blood and into the tissues. A standard scuba diver is breathing a tank of compressed air with a mix similar to regular air (i.e., 20% oxygen).

title: Types of Hyperbaric Oxygen Chambers
content: A mono place chamber–one person inside with the entire air inside the chamber is typically 100% oxygen. A multi place chamber–a chamber where up to 20 people and they typically have a technician that’s inside making sure everybody’s okay. They pressurize the chamber to 2.0-2.5 atmospheres. But the individuals are breathing 100% oxygen through a mask. If they have a seizure in that context of a multi place chamber, you could just take the mask off and they would go from 100% oxygen breathing to a hyperbaric air, which is still elevated in oxygen, but it’s not enough to cause a seizure. Other benefits of HBOT: Immune boosting effects, Stimulates the mobilization (and maybe production) of stem cells, For cancer purposes, it can function as a radiosensitizer, Aids in wound healing, It may helps athletes recover, Possible longevity benefits.

title: Potential role for HBOT in treating COVID-19 patients
content: There is a potential role for hyperbaric oxygen to treat COVID-19 disorders and restore oxygenation. However, there is a big risk in using HBOT on COVID-19 patients as increasing tissue PO2 in the lungs can increase reactive oxygen species, fueling a compromised system just through an increase in redox stress in the lung. Dom thinks it needs to be explored.

title: Non-cancer applications of HBOT
content: HBOT can mobilize stem cells which, once in circulation, hone in on sites of injury and aid in repair and potentially regenerative processes. It can also stimulate the immune system. Some work demonstrates that hyperbaric oxygen increases gene expression of superoxide dismutase and catalase, and maybe glutathione too, through hyperbaric preconditioning. It increases your endogenous antioxidant systems, which in theory could make you more resilient against subsequent oxidative challenges.

title: Keto diet in a hyperbaric environment
content: During his NEEMO 22 mission, Dom lived in a hyperbaric environment for 10 days and stayed at a moderate to high level of ketosis. He reached his lowest glucose ever, and ketones got up to 6.7 and a glucose in the 40s or 50s range. These numbers were typical following his EVAs. He would suit up and work on the ocean floor for up to five hours at a time. Afterwards, he would be mildly hypothermic and his metabolism skyrocketed. That’s when he had his lowest glucose ever and the first time he was able to achieve glucose super low and ketones really high.

title: The inverse relationship between glucose and ketones
content: In terms of a fuel substrate, BHB (ketones) and glucose tend to have an inverse relationship. If you add ketones, the available glucose will lower, and it’s all dependent upon the liver. The liver is the master regulator that choreographs this dynamic interplay between these metabolites. A finely tuned physiological system under a very powerful homeostatic regulation will adjust glucose relative to ketones to the point where they’re inversely proportional. For example, if you take exogenous ketones, you see a drop in your glucose. However, someone with unregulated type 1 diabetes lacks the counterregulatory system associated with control of ketones, without insulin, you have runaway ketogenesis.

title: 2 types of ketoacidosis
content: There are two types of ketoacidosis: 1) Diabetic ketoacidosis, where the counterregulatory mechanisms of insulin are not working. If you’re on a ketogenic diet and then ketones spill into the bloodstream, they feed back to the pancreas and small pulses of insulin will decrease beta oxidation of fatty acids in the liver and reduce ketogenesis. 2) Alcoholic ketoacidosis.

title: Ketogenic diet for type 1 diabetes
content: According to Dom, a low-carb, ketogenic diet is appropriate for those with type 1 diabetes. The insulin dose needs to be adjusted because insulin requirements will be dramatically reduced and this needs to be done under very close supervision with an endocrinologist. Hemoglobin A1C goes into non-diabetic ranges when a person adheres to a low carb ketogenic diet strategy for managing their type 1 diabetes. The low carb protocol is generally modeled after Richard Berstein’s book called Dr. Bernstein’s Diabetes Solution. Just under 50 grams per day of carbohydrates on average basically puts a type 1 diabetic’s hemoglobin A1C into nondiabetic range. It really crushes the glycemic variability. So you have far fewer hyperglycemic events and far fewer hypoglycemic events. And of course, a hypoglycemic event, if you’re on a normal diet could be deadly. But say if your ketones are elevated, you’ll be much more resilient during hypoglycemia. And these hyperglycemic events don’t really realize that they’re happening, but they take a big toll on your body and on your brain and your organs.

title: Ketosis and brain function
content: Ketones function as an alternative fuel for the brain and this can mitigate symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease because a hallmark characteristic of most neurodegenerative diseases is brain glucose hypometabolism. Ketones could be functioning as an alternative fuel to restore brain energy metabolism in the face of glucose hypometabolism. If you’re inhibiting energetic processes in the brain, the amyloid does not clear as fast as it should. That is driven by a number of different factors—Genetically, APOE4 may predispose you to that.

title: Inflammation and Amyloid Production
content: Research is showing that inflammation and processes are associated with an increase in production of amyloid.

title: Ketones and Parkinson's Disease
content: A 2005 paper by Dr. Theodore VanItallie showed that the ketogenic diet could be followed by patients with Parkinson’s disease and it may have lessened or mitigated some of the symptoms. Good scientific preclinical animal model data (and in cell culture) demonstrate that ketones are neuroprotective to dopaminergic neurons. It’s possible that following a ketogenic diet (or supplemental ketosis) over time could prevent dopaminergic neurons from degenerating in the first place.

title: Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Parkinson's Disease
content: Mitochondrial dysfunction is the root cause of Parkinson's disease, according to Dom. Oxidative stress specifically in the dopaminergic neuron population triggers apoptosis and programmed cell death. That can be mitigated in part by an optimal metabolic environment where the mitochondria is functioning efficiently. The function of the mitochondria and mitochondrial health are the ultimate mitigator of neurodegenerative diseases, probably Parkinson’s disease being at the top of that list, just by reducing the potential for reactive oxygen species related damage.

title: Ketosis for Females
content: One study found that 45% of the women in the study that were on a ketogenic diet experienced menstrual dysfunction (e.g., secondary amenorrhea). The ketogenic diet may not be ideal for fertility.

title: Ketones and Fertility
content: Recent animal study showed that an infusion of exogenous ketones suppressed luteinizing hormone (LH), and the response was dependent upon an increase in catecholamines. The implications may be that the ketone infusion—by decreasing LH and elevating ketones—this may help you get leaner, but it’s not going to help you maintain fertility. Ketones may be a signal to the body and the brain that it may not be the best time for child rearing—because if you have low resources (e.g., fasted) you’re going to be in a state of ketosis. Females that have metabolic syndrome and insulin resistant (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS) the ketogenic diet can restore their fertility and restore their hormonal balance.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Women
content: Two studies, (Vargas-Molina et al., 2020 and Gregory et al., 2017), looked at the ketogenic diet for lean body mass and performance in women—The observation was that women on a low carb ketogenic diet could maintain lean body mass and increase performance. A 2005 study looked at fertility and women on low carb ketogenic diets—Two of the women were actually able to get pregnant after being infertile for a period of time. The effect of a low carb diet varies depending on the individual woman—Where they are in terms of metabolic health. The design of the diet—the macronutrient ratios, the source of fats and protein also make a difference. “There needs to be more data for sure. Some of the data indicates that it can be beneficial, especially in women that have metabolic syndrome.”

title: Low-Carb Diets During Pregnancy and Postpartum
content: Be cautious using a purely ketogenic diet during pregnancy. Keto diets dramatically suppress insulin (a growth hormone), and can have great health consequences. However, during pregnancy you want to grow and do not want to impair growth of the developing fetus. In the case of a pregnant woman is obese or a type 2 diabetic, low-carb approach can be very powerful approach, says Dom. Postpartum—Dom has seen multiple examples of women who have trouble producing milk for breastfeeding while on a ketogenic diet—the suppression of insulin signaling for some reason is decreasing lactation and the ability to make milk. That said, Dom has received emails from women saying they had no problem breastfeeding while on a keto diet. So, issues with breastfeeding appears to happen in some percentage of women and not others.

title: High-Protein Diet for Women with Hormonal Issues
content: There is a decrease in leptin associated with ketosis. But there was also an increase in leptin sensitivity. Dom’s thoughts on a higher protein approach for women with hormonal issues— hypothyroidism, peri- and post-menopause, amenorrhea, PCOS, etc. A lot of the issues and side effects that women are experiencing are probably from—Calorie restriction, Overexercising, And suppression of insulin signaling from calorie restriction plus carbohydrate restriction. The insulin suppression impact women more than men in terms of maintaining a hormone balance (especially with the sex hormones). Periodically increasing protein into your diet may be beneficial for women to avoid some of the potential counterregulatory hormonal effects that can occur through insulin suppression associated with the ketogenic diet.

title: Nutritional tips for remaining metabolically flexible
content: When using a diet therapeutically, it’s important to maintain insulin suppression and low blood glucose and ketones. For a normal, healthy person using the ketogenic diet as a lifestyle, it’s about being metabolically flexible. Spiking insulin into the moderate range a few times a week can really be beneficial to assist in recovery, but to also keep that energetic pathway open. A super strict ketogenic diet all the time is going to produce some level of physiological insulin resistance that is not advantageous.

title: In utero experiments, and other interesting questions Dom wants to explore
content: Dom is very interested in doing in utero experiments on disorders that we already know are responsive to the ketogenic diet (e.g., cancer and genetic disorders). If genetic testing revealed that the baby was going to have a genetic disease that we know already responds to therapeutic ketosis, such as Glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome, Kabuki syndrome, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, different seizure disorders, and neurometabolic disorders. Additionally, Dom would like to explore in utero experiments where you feed the mom high-fructose corn syrup, oxidized fats, trans fats, glyphosate, chemicals and follow the offspring to see if there’s an increase in disease. People with glucose transporter type 1 (GLUT1) deficiency syndrome, do not seem to get cancer.

title: The anti-catabolic effect of ketones, cancer cachexia, and nutritional interventions for cancer patients
content: Cancer cachexia is a wasting syndrome that occurs in cancer patients. The anti-catabolic effect of ketones can help prevent muscle wasting in cancer patients. Nutritional interventions for cancer patients can help improve their quality of life and reduce the side effects of treatment.

title: Ketogenic diet for cancer patients
content: People like Tom Seyfried is making the case that the ketogenic diet should be standard of care for people with cancer. Anti-catabolic effects of ketones may be able to mitigate cancer cachexia. Evolutionary mechanism by which ketones are anti-catabolic. One major pathway found by Andrew Koutnik is that it inhibits specific inflammatory pathways that are driving cancer cachexia. We need engineered foods for cancer patients that are carbohydrate restricted, moderate in protein, and have natural additives that have anti-cancer properties.

title: Nutrition for cancer patients
content: Ensure—the dietary drink commonly given to cancer patients . . . “is not the solution. . .that should be criminal.” says Dom. We need engineered foods for cancer patients that are carbohydrate restricted, moderate in protein, and have natural additives that have anti-cancer properties. Omega-3 fatty acids can also have an anticatabolic anti-cancer cachexia effect.

title: Quantifying Nutrition
content: And there could be some system that would quantify it and tell us if we’re doing a good job and redirect our thinking in a way to where we could promote actionable behavior that would move the human species in the right direction.
